object.content:
Feeling happier after switching my regular doom-scrolling habits for some refreshing algorithm-free RSS.

Curating a list of feeds I care about is nice.
Still thinking about how I make new discoveries without being overwhelmed.

Get RSS on your sites, y'all.

contentMap.en:
Feeling happier after switching my regular doom-scrolling habits for some refreshing algorithm-free RSS.

Curating a list of feeds I care about is nice.
Still thinking about how I make new discoveries without being overwhelmed.

Get RSS on your sites, y'all.

object.content:
Also motivated as a result of these times to make a return to regularly posting on my own site, which has an RSS feed that will become more active again.

https://www.hawksworx.com/feed.xml

object.content:
Also encouraged by the crossposting from Twitter to Mastadon to reduce friction as I explore transitioning to a new home.

https://crossposter.masto.donte.com.br/ makes it very simple to originate posts in just one place and crosspost in whichever direction you like

https://indieweb.social/@philhawksworth/109326619594920944

object.content:
Speaking of RSS, it's going to be so trivial to surface posts from my new Mastadon profile on my personal site thanks to the automatic RSS feed provided there by simply adding .rss to my profile page.

https://indieweb.social/@philhawksworth.rss

Calling in at Northwestern University on my way home from San Francisco to see my talented nephew perform in the Symphonic Wind Ensemble.

Excited.

contentMap.en:
Calling in at Northwestern University on my way home from San Francisco to see my talented nephew perform in the Symphonic Wind Ensemble.

Excited.

attachment.name: A hand holding up a program for the Symphonic Wind Ensemble at Northwestern University in the foreground from a perfect seat, in the auditorium.

object.content:
@martinhelmut O confess, I think very little about the issue of losing ad revenue from content being read via RSS rather thank on site.

I suspect that there is a massive cohort of site owners for whom this is a non-issue, and I’m eager to encourage them.

For others, publishing an excerpt rather than the full article can actually be a good discovery and inbound traffic generator.

contentMap.en:
@martinhelmut O confess, I think very little about the issue of losing ad revenue from content being read via RSS rather thank on site.

I suspect that there is a massive cohort of site owners for whom this is a non-issue, and I’m eager to encourage them.

For others, publishing an excerpt rather than the full article can actually be a good discovery and inbound traffic generator.

object.content:
Twitter has been such a big part of my professional life and facilitated so many connections and friendships for me over the years.

I really fear for it now.

Grabbing my data before it's too late.
Just in case.

Find yours via https://twitter.com/settings/account

contentMap.en:
Twitter has been such a big part of my professional life and facilitated so many connections and friendships for me over the years.

I really fear for it now.

Grabbing my data before it's too late.
Just in case.

Find yours via https://twitter.com/settings/account

object.content:
If like me and many others, you're in the process of moving your tweets to a new home on your own site, a word of caution:

Tweets to twitter circles are not labelled as such in the export, so be aware of the risk of making public what you might have intended for a trusted group

contentMap.en:
If like me and many others, you're in the process of moving your tweets to a new home on your own site, a word of caution:

Tweets to twitter circles are not labelled as such in the export, so be aware of the risk of making public what you might have intended for a trusted group

object.content: @hankchizljaw I've not been very active/spicy in many circles... but still want a solution for this before I publish my archive on my site

contentMap.en: @hankchizljaw I've not been very active/spicy in many circles... but still want a solution for this before I publish my archive on my site

object.content:
@hankchizljaw Ha!

I'm not comfortable with the long look in the mirror that deciding what my wheat-to-chaff ratio has been... but I've always wanted to retain my content on URLs, so I want to publish everything I've chosen to post publicly

contentMap.en:
@hankchizljaw Ha!

I'm not comfortable with the long look in the mirror that deciding what my wheat-to-chaff ratio has been... but I've always wanted to retain my content on URLs, so I want to publish everything I've chosen to post publicly

object.content:
@jhey I got you!

You want to create a Build Hook for your site in your Build & Deploy settings, and then call it each day with a scheduled function (using fetch to issue a POST request)

https://docs.netlify.com/functions/scheduled-functions/#cron-expression-inline-in-function-code

contentMap.en:
@jhey I got you!

You want to create a Build Hook for your site in your Build & Deploy settings, and then call it each day with a scheduled function (using fetch to issue a POST request)

https://docs.netlify.com/functions/scheduled-functions/#cron-expression-inline-in-function-code

attachment.name: A screenshot of the Deploy Hooks section of Netlify's Build & Deploy settings

object.content: @jhey You get a pretty nice artifact as it goes. All the data is in JSON (which I'll use to populate a section of my own site) and it has a little local site wrapper to let you explore.

contentMap.en: @jhey You get a pretty nice artifact as it goes. All the data is in JSON (which I'll use to populate a section of my own site) and it has a little local site wrapper to let you explore.

attachment.name: A short screen recording of exploring the archive of content exported from Twitter

object.content: @jhey Excellent! Looking forward to seeing it.

contentMap.en: @jhey Excellent! Looking forward to seeing it.

object.content: @jhey GET IN!

contentMap.en: @jhey GET IN!

object.content:
@jhey Yeah.

The data dump is there too, which is useful. But yes, the little site you get for exploring it is nice.

I wish the data made a note of tweets that you posted into a circle though. That's given me pause.

And it doesn't include bookmarks.

Mine took about 24 hours to arrive after requesting it.

contentMap.en:

object.content:
@hankchizljaw Yeah I've been thinking that too.

I'm not settled yet on deleting my tweets such as @beep and others are doing. But once I've published my own, I'll at least pin a tweet which points to their new home, noting that the id numbers in the URL match.

In time I might delete all from twitter other that this one bit of guidance on where to find that missing tweet on that now broken URL

contentMap.en:
@hankchizljaw Yeah I've been thinking that too.

object.content:
@youknowjack I'm taking the json file of my tweets, provided in the export, and cleaning it up a little to remove properties I'll not need. Which brings it down from ~50MB to ~8MB.

Then I'll use this is a data file in my site which is built with @eleventy, to generate a page for each, some pages listing them all, and a simple search that I'll build.

My site is set to get a `/notes` section to hold those and future social media postings.

Locally 26.5k pages build in ~4s at present

contentMap.en:
@youknowjack I'm taking the json file of my tweets, provided in the export, and cleaning it up a little to remove properties I'll not need. Which brings it down from ~50MB to ~8MB.

Then I'll use this is a data file in my site which is built with @eleventy, to generate a page for each, some pages listing them all, and a simple search that I'll build.

My site is set to get a `/notes` section to hold those and future social media postings.

Locally 26.5k pages build in ~4s at present

@beep @hankchizljaw

Hello hello! 👋

It's really rather refreshing so far!

object.content:
My silly old demo of how easily and readily a site could be deployed has morphed into a demo of how fiddly timezone data can now be provided for every user request with #Netlify Edge Functions

https://setyourwatchby.netlify.app/

contentMap.en:
My silly old demo of how easily and readily a site could be deployed has morphed into a demo of how fiddly timezone data can now be provided for every user request with #Netlify Edge Functions

https://setyourwatchby.netlify.app/

attachment.name:
A fragment of code showing how a Netlify Edge Function can provide the timezone and preferred language of the user making each request.

Available in more detail as text here: https://github.com/philhawksworth/html-time/blob/686a6f6365d17fc691029437cd716aefec7641a7/netlify/edge-functions/time.ts#L5-L10

object.content:

object.content:
Are Direct Messages in #Mastodon actually private messages or just replies?

Asking due to some uncertainty I'm feeling from the UI

Are Direct Messages in #Mastodon actually private messages or just replies?

object.content:
@karin @whitep4nth3r Ah. Yes. You do indeed.

Some hints are there, but this does need a little more awareness in order to not make a public gaff IMO.

Knowing that @-ing someone adds them to the thread is an important detail.

contentMap.en:
@karin @whitep4nth3r Ah. Yes. You do indeed.

object.content:
@ask Thanks!

I've learned that by mentioning somebody with @, you'll add them to the DM thread from that point on. Which is an important detail to know, I think.

object.content:
My friends, Cassie and Jo, have shown courage by being among the first to speak publicly about this.

I only quietly withdrew from this event, so I did not get challenged online. I wish I had listened to my instincts and the accounts of countless other speakers sooner.

RT @cassiecodes@twitter.com

One of my friends spoke out about her experience with Modern Frontends.

I have some things to say too.

It seems like a lot of people do.

https://www.cassie.codes/posts/modern-frontends

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/cassiecodes/status/1593675948410507266

contentMap.en:

object.content: @cobra_winfrey Yes. I trust Cassie completely. But on this occasion I didn’t need to base anything just on trust. I’ve heard accounts directly from many speakers for the event that tally. And they fit with my own experience.

contentMap.en: @cobra_winfrey Yes. I trust Cassie completely. But on this occasion I didn’t need to base anything just on trust. I’ve heard accounts directly from many speakers for the event that tally. And they fit with my own experience.

object.content:
@ppk @seb_ly FWIW, sponsors were approached with the claim that they were expecting 3000 speakers. The only reason to book a venue of that size is if you’re hoping to bring in that many attendees. And Also the only way to avoid just a handful of attendees per talk.

I think this is an example of their reach far outstretching their grasp.

contentMap.en:
@ppk @seb_ly FWIW, sponsors were approached with the claim that they were expecting 3000 speakers. The only reason to book a venue of that size is if you’re hoping to bring in that many attendees. And Also the only way to avoid just a handful of attendees per talk.

I think this is an example of their reach far outstretching their grasp.

object.content: @ppk @seb_ly I fear you may be right.

contentMap.en: @ppk @seb_ly I fear you may be right.

object.content:
@hdv @ppk @seb_ly That’s what they told me too. And was why I was ok to waive my speaker fee.

I think it’s fine to have the *profits* from an event subsidise another, but not at the expense of the participants and attendees. And telling people who’ve paid large sums that they’ll not get the expected facilities is not ok. Trust will vanish and the whole thing will not be repeatable.

contentMap.en:
@hdv @ppk @seb_ly That’s what they told me too. And was why I was ok to waive my speaker fee.

I think it’s fine to have the *profits* from an event subsidise another, but not at the expense of the participants and attendees. And telling people who’ve paid large sums that they’ll not get the expected facilities is not ok. Trust will vanish and the whole thing will not be repeatable.

@loftio Asking somebody to donate a full day workshop ticketed at £900-1100 per person is an absolute grift. Shameless.

object.content:
A question about #Mastodon etiquette and behaviours —

Are company accounts reasonable here? I'm happy to see a number of conferences, meetups, and open source projects surfacing in my timeline here now, but I'm not really seeing company's operating an account.

Can company accounts exist here and behave nicely? Do we want that?

Asking for a friend. (Who might be a company)

@charis Totally! I quite like the idea of a company having their own instance so that they're not taking slurping up the capacity of a popular instance. Although they could of course contribute to help fund it.

But then again it might be a sign of being a better citizen to host their own. It also avoids popular companies getting too much influence over community instances.

object.content:
@michaelklein @zachleat I did something similar for a bit.

Stage 1, seeing if Mastodon suited me:
Crosspost my tweets to here.

Stage 2, happy here. Leave breadcrumbs:
Switch to crossposting toots to twitter.

Stage 3, giving up on twitter:
Remove crossposting and get comfy here.

Feeling pretty at ease going quiet over there now, and just participating in what feels like a much more constructive environment here.

contentMap.en:
@michaelklein @zachleat I did something similar for a bit.

Stage 1, seeing if Mastodon suited me:
Crosspost my tweets to here.

Stage 2, happy here. Leave breadcrumbs:
Switch to crossposting toots to twitter.

Stage 3, giving up on twitter:
Remove crossposting and get comfy here.

Feeling pretty at ease going quiet over there now, and just participating in what feels like a much more constructive environment here.

object.content:
This is good to see.

https://remix.run/blog/open-development

And as @biilmann said over on twitter, "Open source done with secret roadmaps and surprise launches is very different from a truly open collaborative processes that allow all users of the project to plan ahead and align around future roadmap items."

I heartily agree. Bravo, Remix team!

object.content:
@peduarte This sounds brilliant.

I'd like to coordinate with you on planning/building it. Our API is pretty well documented and is core to how we expose more features (everything tends to sit on top of our API, so if something is possible via the admin app or CLI, you can expect it to be possible via the API)

I can help connect people to liaise on this.

contentMap.en:
@peduarte This sounds brilliant.

I'd like to coordinate with you on planning/building it. Our API is pretty well documented and is core to how we expose more features (everything tends to sit on top of our API, so if something is possible via the admin app or CLI, you can expect it to be possible via the API)

I can help connect people to liaise on this.

object.content:
@peduarte We have a few folks around the company who use Raycast already, and I'm interested to explore what's possible with teams.

We'll likely start with just a small number of us on the free tier for teams, and then ramp up from there. My instinct is that we'll quickly see value in this for some of our common shared tasks and commands, so stepping into the paid tier will become an easier decision.

contentMap.en:
@peduarte We have a few folks around the company who use Raycast already, and I'm interested to explore what's possible with teams.

We'll likely start with just a small number of us on the free tier for teams, and then ramp up from there. My instinct is that we'll quickly see value in this for some of our common shared tasks and commands, so stepping into the paid tier will become an easier decision.

object.content:
"I've looked at *everything*, there's no way I'm missing something silly or obvious."

Narrator: He was.

contentMap.en:
"I've looked at *everything*, there's no way I'm missing something silly or obvious."

Narrator: He was.

object.content:
It's been fun adding the archive of my tweets to my own site.

https://www.hawksworx.com/notes/

- Index of all tweets paginated into ~1000 pre-gen pages
- ODB (on-demand) render + cache of any specific tweet page
- Speedy (but basic for now) searching with Edge Functions

contentMap.en:

object.content: @henry oh thanks! I’m long overdue an update… which might be my holiday project.

object.content:
@cl Thanks so much!

I rolled my own, and I’ll blog about it tomorrow, but you can also use something like Tweetback to get a very similar result without too much fuss.

https://github.com/tweetback/tweetback

object.content:
A little update: I've just learned that while this is true in the `tweets.js` file that contains all of your tweets, you can cross-reference that with the `twitter-circle-tweet.js` to find things you posted into circles.

Caution is still needed if, like me, you roll your own archive view of your tweets. But the data is present in your export after all. Just in a different file from from your tweets.

contentMap.en:
A little update: I've just learned that while this is true in the `tweets.js` file that contains all of your tweets, you can cross-reference that with the `twitter-circle-tweet.js` to find things you posted into circles.

Caution is still needed if, like me, you roll your own archive view of your tweets. But the data is present in your export after all. Just in a different file from from your tweets.

object.content: Today I saw what *real* passion and commitment looks like, when @DavidDarnes started telling me about the different levels of filling he'd encountered in various brands of mince pies.

contentMap.en: Today I saw what *real* passion and commitment looks like, when @DavidDarnes started telling me about the different levels of filling he'd encountered in various brands of mince pies.
